Then it turns out they were not finding the best deals, but the deals the stores wanted the customer to use. Say there is a 50% and 20% coupons floating around out there. The stores would have Honey only show you the 20%. Once again this is way over simplified.

Author: katiescasey

Comment: In all fairness, I wouldn‚Äôt really expect them to get the ‚Äúbest‚Äù deals‚Äîit may be cynical, but that‚Äôs simply not how American companies work anymore. Consumers who wouldn‚Äôt otherwise think to research what deals are out there will be perfectly happy with the 20% off, so it just kind of makes sense for Honey to take advantage of that without going much further. If they make the best deals easily accessible, they risk getting crushed by the larger companies (off the top of my head, by making, say, the Sephora website incompatible with the Honey app). I had Honey a few years ago, and about once every 6 months it gave me an excellent deal I wouldn‚Äôt have otherwise found, but it just as often said there were NO available deals, even when the website itself was advertising a code. Horribly inconsistent, but it‚Äôs not like it costs anything. If people are using Honey and thinking it is always giving them the best option, that‚Äôs kinda on them.

Comment: You misunderstood. Honey is overriding all other referrers, "sniping" the sale to get the commission. That's the fraud

Author: HyperactivePandah

Comment: I'm just saying I'm realizing this happening in a lot of places, and no, I just had no idea. TikTok does this by intentionally throttling their own branded sales and discounts over the benefits of creators and the stores themselves. They brand it as "helping" the stores do higher volume but force vendors into sub margin sale prices. TikTok still gets their commission on the sale, and if the brand ships with TikTok too.
